text: Administration of William J. Clinton, 1995 / Feb. 27
label: BODY

text: today who represent the strong partnership
label: BODY

text: in disaster response between the Red Cross
label: BODY

text: and AmeriCorps, our national service pro-
label: BODY

text: gram. Johnny Jones and Beverly Beyer were
label: BODY

text: trained by you, the Red Cross. They’ve
label: BODY

text: worked side by side with the Red Cross when
label: BODY

text: disaster struck in Idaho during fires and
label: BODY

text: Houston after the flood. I’m proud of them
label: BODY

text: and the spirit of voluntarism they represent.
label: BODY

text: I’d like them to raise their hands and be rec-
label: BODY

text: ognized. There they are. Thank you very
label: BODY

text: much. [Applause]
label: BODY

text: Now I have to do what Elizabeth sent me
label: BODY

text: here to do, the sales pitch. [Laughter] Be-
label: BODY

text: cause the truth is that for all the work the
label: BODY

text: Red Cross does, none of it can happen with-
label: BODY

text: out the generous support of the American
label: BODY

text: people, without the million and a half volun-
label: BODY

text: teers, the millions of financial contributors,
label: BODY

text: and yes, the blood donors.
label: BODY

text: So I urge all Americans to keep up your
label: BODY

text: support, to give your time, to give your
label: BODY

text: money, to give your blood, because, as the
label: BODY

text: saying is this year, ‘‘Help Can’t Wait.’’ I hope
label: BODY

text: the Americ an people will continue to live
label: BODY

text: out the ideals of the Red Cross and be good
label: BODY

text: neighbors every day.
label: BODY

text: Thank you very much, and God bless you.
label: BODY

text: NOTE: The President spoke at 11:26 a.m. on the
label: BODY

text: lawn at Red Cross headquarters. Following his re-
label: BODY

text: marks and a tour of displays, he signed the Amer-
label: BODY

text: ican Red Cross Month proclamation.
label: BODY

text: Proclamation 6772—American Red
label: HH1

text: Cross Month, 1995
label: BODY

text: February 27, 1995
label: BODY

text: By the President of the United States
label: BODY

text: of America
label: BODY

text: A Proclamation
label: BODY

text: Every day, thousands of people in need
label: BODY

text: look to the American Red Cross as a banner
label: BODY

text: of hope. For disaster victims here and
label: BODY

text: abroad, for service men and women seeking
label: BODY

text: assistance, and for everyone depending on
label: BODY

text: a safe and ready supply of blood—the Red
label: BODY

text: Cross stands prepared to respond. But the
label: BODY

text: scope of its service extends well beyond the
label: BODY

text: provision of emergency care. Its broader mis-
label: BODY

text: sion is clear: to promote compassion, to fos-
label: BODY

text: ter a spirit of generosity, and to improve the
label: BODY

text: human condition everywhere.
label: BODY

text: Since Clara Barton—‘‘The Angel of the
label: BODY

text: Battlefield’’—founded the American Associa-
label: BODY

text: tion of the Red Cross in 1881, its members
label: BODY

text: have been called upon to serve in war and
label: BODY

text: in peace. Today, with more than 1 million
label: BODY

text: dedicated and experienced volunteers, the
label: BODY

text: American Red Cross plays a vital role in
label: BODY

text: bringing physical and emotional comfort to
label: BODY

text: those who need it most. Whether they are
label: BODY

text: responding to an emergency or addressing
label: BODY

text: the daily necessities of the homeless and el-
label: BODY

text: derly, Red Cross workers have always been
label: BODY

text: models of community spirit.
label: BODY

text: Dangers to the health and safety of our
label: BODY

text: people have changed radically during the
label: BODY

text: past hundred years, and the Red Cross has
label: BODY

text: adapted to meet these needs. Its commit-
label: BODY

text: ment to caring for others enables us to re-
label: BODY

text: store hope in the lives of injured citizens,
label: BODY

text: and its example challenges us to revitalize
label: BODY

text: the covenant of American citizenship. The
label: BODY

text: long-term strength of our Nation depends
label: BODY

text: upon our willingness to live out the ideals
label: BODY

text: long embodied by the American Red Cross.
label: BODY

text: To celebrate our past and to safeguard our
label: BODY

text: future, I am proud to commend the countless
label: BODY

text: individuals whose courage and selflessness
label: BODY

text: have sustained this organization for more
label: BODY

text: than a century.
label: BODY

text: Now, Therefore, I, William J. Clinton,
label: BODY

text: President of the United States of America
label: BODY

text: and Honorary Chairman of the American
label: BODY

text: Red Cross, by virtue of the authority vested
label: BODY

text: in me by the Constitution and laws of the
label: BODY

text: United States, do hereby proclaim March
label: BODY

text: 1995 as ‘‘American Red Cross Month.’’ I urge
label: BODY

text: all Americans to show support for the more
label: BODY

text: than 2,000 Red Cross chapters nationwide,
label: BODY

text: and I challenge each of you to become active
label: BODY

text: participants in advancing the noble mission
label: BODY

text: of the Red Cross.
label: BODY

text: In Witness Whereof, I have hereunto set
label: BODY

text: my hand this twenty-seventh day of Feb-
label: BODY

text: ruary, in the year of our Lord nineteen hun-
label: BODY

text: dred and ninety-five, and of the Independ-
label: BODY

text: ence of the United States of America the two
label: BODY

text: hundred and nineteenth.
label: BODY

text: William Jefferson Clinton
label: BODY

text: [Filed with the Office of the Federal Register,
label: BODY

text: Feb. 27 / Administration of William J. Clinton, 1995
label: BODY

text: NOTE: This proclamation was published in the
label: BODY

text: Federal Register on March 2.
label: BODY

text: Remarks Commemorating the First
label: HH2

text: Anniversary of the Brady Law and an
label: BODY

text: Exchange With Reporters
label: BODY

text: February 28, 1995
label: BODY

text: The President. Thank you very much. Mr.
label: BODY

text: Vice President, Mr. Secretary, Madam Attor-
label: BODY

text: ney General, Commissioner Lovitt, and my
label: BODY

text: friend Jim, congratulations. Happy anniver-
label: BODY

text: sary.
label: BODY

text: You know, I’d like to begin by saying a
label: BODY

text: special word about Jim Brady. He dedicated
label: BODY

text: his life to public service. In no small measure
label: BODY

text: because of that dedication, 14 years ago his
label: BODY

text: life was in danger and his life changed for-
label: BODY

text: ever. In spite of all the hardship and the pain
label: BODY

text: that followed, he never looked back but in-
label: BODY

text: stead decided he should fight on, determined
label: BODY

text: to do his part to prevent the tragedy that
label: BODY

text: struck him from striking other people. More
label: BODY

text: than any other person in the United States,
label: BODY

text: we celebrate today the courage and deter-
label: BODY

text: mination of Jim Brady, and we are in his
label: BODY

text: debt.
label: BODY

text: Thank you, sir.
label: BODY

text: James Brady. Thank you, sir.
label: BODY

text: The President. You know, Jim and Sarah
label: BODY

text: Brady represent in so many ways the kind
label: BODY

text: of citizen action I talked about in the State
label: BODY

text: of the Union Address, the New Covenant:
label: BODY

text: moral responsibility along with more oppor-
label: BODY

text: tunity and people sparking grassroots move-
label: BODY

text: ments across this country. I am committed
label: BODY

text: to this law and committed to what it rep-
label: BODY

text: resents. You know, our big problems here
label: BODY

text: in Washington often stem from the fact that
label: BODY

text: we don’t think about what promotes respon-
label: BODY

text: sibility and what creates opportunity and
label: BODY

text: what enables people to make the most of
label: BODY

text: their own lives. The Brady bill does all that.
label: BODY

text: A crucial part of our job here in Washing-
label: BODY

text: ton is to help arm the American people,
label: BODY

text: through our police officers, to fight crime
label: BODY

text: and violence. The Brady law, in that sense,
label: BODY

text: is one of the things that I’m proudest of that
label: BODY

text: has happened since I have been President.
label: BODY

text: We put an end to 7 years of politics-as-usual,
label: BODY

text: of people saying one thing and doing another,
label: BODY

text: when the Brady law passed. It’s not a com-
label: BODY

text: plex piece of legislation, but it took 7 years,
label: BODY

text: 7 years to pass the Congress.
label: BODY

text: And all the naysayers talked about how ter-
label: BODY

text: rible it would be. Well, now we know that,
label: BODY

text: as the Secretary said, over 40,000 convicted
label: BODY

text: felons, fugitives, drug dealers, gang mem-
label: BODY

text: bers, stalkers, were prevented from purchas-
label: BODY

text: ing handguns in the Brady law’s first 11
label: BODY

text: months. I should point out that the real na-
label: BODY

text: tional number is bigger than that because,
label: BODY

text: as you know, there are some States that have
label: BODY

text: companion laws that go along with that, and
label: BODY

text: the estimates are that, nationwide in the
label: BODY

text: States with Brady-like laws and the Brady
label: BODY

text: law, the total is more like 70,000.
label: BODY

text: A recent study says that, as the Secretary
label: BODY

text: said, that that’s only 3.5 percent of all the
label: BODY

text: people who buy handguns. And as he said,
label: BODY

text: it’s kind of like airport metal detectors. I
label: BODY

text: think 97 percent of us should be willing to
label: BODY

text: wait a while, so that the 3 percent of us who
label: BODY

text: are trying to buy guns for the wrong reasons
label: BODY

text: can be stopped. Three percent of the Amer-
label: BODY

text: ican people buying guns for the wrong rea-
label: BODY

text: sons can do a phenomenal amount of dam-
label: BODY

text: age, and stopping them can do a phenomenal
label: BODY

text: amount of good, can keep a lot of citizens
label: BODY

text: alive, and it can keep an awful lot of law en-
label: BODY

text: forcement officials alive.
label: BODY

text: There are thousands of examples around
label: BODY

text: the country, but let me just cite one or two.
label: BODY

text: In March of 1994, the Brady law stopped
label: BODY

text: a handgun purchase by a man in Kansas
label: BODY

text: under a restraining order for allegedly stalk-
label: BODY

text: ing his wife and threatening to kill her. In
label: BODY

text: April, the law led to the arrest of a suspected
label: BODY

text: drug dealer in Texas with outstanding war-
label: BODY

text: rants for possession of cocaine and heroin
label: BODY

text: with intent to distribute. In November, it
label: BODY

text: helped to catch two gang members, both
label: BODY

text: convicted felons, who traveled all the way
label: BODY

text: from California to Nevada to purchase weap-
label: BODY

text: ons.
label: BODY

text: These are the people the law was meant
label: BODY

text: to stop. Law-abiding people are those the law
label: BODY

text: was meant to protect. The test was simple:
label: BODY

text: Will it save a life? Will it protect one child
label: BODY

text: walking home from school, so he or she could
label: BODY

text: feel a little safer? Will it spare one woman
label: BODY

text: from abuse? If it could, we all thought the
label: BODY

text: law would be a success. Now we know that
label: BODY

text: it has done that thousands of times over in
label: BODY
